reviews.text: Gravity is arguably the best 3-D movie of all-time and it's an experience we've never seen before at the theater.
reviews.author: JD Duran

reviews.text: While there is no way to truly re-create the wholly immersive theatrical experience of "Gravity" at home, the newly reissued Blu-ray comes closest — reintroducing a powerful Dolby Atmos sound mix and intriguing extra features into a more affordable orbit.
reviews.author: Nick Rogers

reviews.text: Gravity is a thrilling technical achievement unlike any other space thriller.
reviews.author: Danielle Solzman

reviews.text: This is virtuoso film-making on every level.
reviews.author: Kevin Maher

reviews.text: Their [Sandra Bullock and George Clooney] fight for survival against the odds is so brilliantly realised that you forgive the implausible plot.
reviews.author: Wendy Ide

reviews.text: ...the work of an efficient master dominating his artistic form.
reviews.author: Wael Khairy

reviews.text: Gravity might still stand out as a technical achievement, but viewing the film after the release of films like Interstellar and The Martian, fails to stand out as super impressive or engaging overall.
reviews.author: Carson Timar

reviews.text: Though the narrative doesn’t contain all of the dramatic pull implied by the title, for its technical and visceral achievements, Gravity is still something of a visual revelation.
reviews.author: Brian Eggert

reviews.text: For me the initial experience was unforgettable. Completely original, strikingly bold, and brilliantly made.
reviews.author: Keith Garlington

reviews.text: While its screenplay doesn't entirely take off, its sound and visuals make this journey into outer space an unforgettable cinematic experience.
reviews.author: Cody Dericks

reviews.text: A taut thrill ride.
reviews.author: Alex Behan

reviews.text: If you want utter spectacle in the most realistic way possible, Alfonso Cuarón's Gravity may have been the in-theater experience of the decade.
reviews.author: Nathan Mattise

reviews.text: A few twists and unpredictable scenarios pop up to keep the intrigue alive for an impressive length, but a lack of solid character development and plot cheapens the momentum.
reviews.author: Mike Massie

reviews.text: Gravity doesn't so much immerse you in its cinematic experience as it simply takes you there and sets you down among the stars.
reviews.author: Richard Propes

reviews.text: [Gravity] is not just a spectacle that shows us the beauty and horrors of space but also a survival tale and a tale about grief.
reviews.author: Shikhar Verma

reviews.text: As a sci-fi geek, Gravity naturally ticks all the boxes that I expect from a sci-fi film and reminds me why I fell in love with the genre in the first place.
reviews.author: Kelechi Ehenulo

reviews.text: By turns chilling, engaging, and breathtaking, Gravity juxtaposes the serenity of extreme quiet with moments of swirling, chaotic terror as it hurtles through space.
reviews.author: Brent McKnight

reviews.text: At the end of the getaway, 'Gravity' is a film that will be talked about for many years to come, and not because of the realistic approach to space, but because of its technical originality. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Yasser Medina

reviews.text: It was well made.
reviews.author: Andrew Galdi

reviews.text: I was never bored.
reviews.author: Avaryl Halley

reviews.text: Cuarón has created an absolutely singular experience that is a marvel to watch.
reviews.author: David Harris

reviews.text: Cuaron's journey into space is a great achievement, pushing the limits of what we can do with technology on screen and hinting at where it can go in the future.
reviews.author: Kirsten Acuna

reviews.text: Bullock's dizzyingly complex performance in a film that is as thrilling as it is culturally resonant makes Gravity something hella special.
reviews.author: Ryan Syrek

reviews.text: It literally takes your breath away, yet it's a triumph of weightless entertainment sans gravitas. Not that there's anything wrong with that. Escape doesn't get much better.
reviews.author: Brian D. Johnson

reviews.text: It will reinvigorate your love of movies.
reviews.author: Leslie Combemale

reviews.text: There are some truly incredible sequences in here, and for a studio tentpole it's quite original, but don't expect a masterpiece.
reviews.author: C.J. Prince

reviews.text: A wondrous experience, a space epic on a grand and rare scale that is one of this year's can't miss films.
reviews.author: Mattie Lucas

reviews.text: Believe the hype.
reviews.author: David Brake

reviews.text: It's unlike anything you've ever seen - full of breathtaking visuals that should be witnessed on the biggest screen you can find.
reviews.author: Micheal Compton

reviews.text: This won't be the film many were expecting but as pure spectacle cinema, Gravity is breathtaking.
reviews.author: Craig Williams

reviews.text: By the time Gravity concludes at the end of its ninety minutes, we are exhausted. The filmmakers have convinced us that we are part of what we are witnessing, making for one of the most tense and intense movies imaginable.
reviews.author: Abbie Bernstein

reviews.text: A singular survival tale in space, Gravity is an experience that marvels and mesmerizes.
reviews.author: Nathalia Aryani

reviews.text: ...a very simplistic story against some incredible achievement in visual effects and filmmaking craft.
reviews.author: Tara Judah

reviews.text: It's hard to deny the spectatorial awe that Cuarón has engendered by the story's end as the film's very title (and theme) of gravity reaches a moving and emotional conclusion.
reviews.author: PJ Nabarro

reviews.text: ...[a] wondrous package of technological achievement. The human feelings of hopelessness and the instinctual need to exist in the madness of fear and frustration is the calling card that really gives this game-changing gem its captivating conviction
reviews.author: Frank Ochieng

reviews.text: It is complex and profound without being pretentious or pedantic. In fact, if anything, its simplicity highlights the film's depth and study in contrasts. I thought it was a moving, beautiful, unique movie.
reviews.author: Debbie Baldwin

reviews.text: It's got all the spectacle that your average audience wants to see, but also has enough thought and artistry to satisfy the true cinephile as well.
reviews.author: Jennifer Heaton

reviews.text: May be the densest visual experience ever made. The disorientation is physical, visceral -- the audience I was with limped out of the cinema grasping at chair arms for balance.
reviews.author: Stephen Marche

reviews.text: Gravity really is the closest 99.99% of us will ever get to being in space, and it was beautiful.
reviews.author: Aaron Peterson

reviews.text: The screenwriters fill this chamber piece in space with loads of sentimentality.
reviews.author: Pat Padua

reviews.text: The searing action is never repetitive, and every frame is inspired. I'll pay to see this thrilling and wonderfully realized survival adventure again because the visual elements,... made the film taunt with breath-catching tension.
reviews.author: Lapacazo Magrira Sandoval

reviews.text: What makes this by far the best film of the year is not the haiku-like storyline or Stone's heart-stopping scramble... but the tears. Gravity is one of the most outrageously emotionally manipulative films I have ever seen.
reviews.author: Camilla Long

reviews.text: Those of us who have never traveled beyond the earth's atmosphere -- hell, maybe even those who have -- will be easily convinced that Cuaron's outer space is the real deal.
reviews.author: Ellen Killoran

reviews.text: It's horrifying (and gorgeous), and you'll be thankful you're planted securely in your theater seat.
reviews.author: Al Hoff

reviews.text: This certain best-picture nominee sounds almost as good as it looks.
reviews.author: Christopher Lawrence

reviews.text: It's an amazing feat of filmmaking, but where Cuarón should have applied similar elbow grease was on the script.
reviews.author: Tom Meek

reviews.text: Gravity is a movie of elegant beauty and surprising emotional power.
reviews.author: Barbara Vancheri

reviews.text: The hype for Cuarón's ambitious Gravity has been . . . well . . . out of this world. Critics have fallen over themselves praising the film and I went into the theater expecting very big things indeed. I hate to say this, but I didn't love it.
reviews.author: Alexandra MacAaron

reviews.text: Gravity should be getting award consideration in several categories. Its spectacular cinematography creates a powerful juxtaposition between the sublime beauty of the cosmos and its powerful isolation.
reviews.author: Josh Terry

reviews.text: Cuaron keeps his film as realistic as it can get. No melodrama, no far-fetched stylised action scenes or convenient plot twists. The film stays unpredictable till the end.
reviews.author: Renuka Vyavahare

reviews.text: I adore this movie on every level...
reviews.author: Sarah Marrs

reviews.text: Whatever is achieved here visually is never really matched by a profound narrative.
reviews.author: Alexandra Zawia

reviews.text: With its themes of spirituality, religion, birth, rebirth and hope, Gravity is a film that will move audiences in different ways. That's the beauty of it; it transcends genres, generations and time, a modern classic.
reviews.author: Candice Frederick

reviews.text: A survival drama set almost entirely in the unfathomable abyss of outer space, Gravity is something now quite rare -- a truly popular big-budget Hollywood movie with a rich aesthetic pay-off.
reviews.author: J. Hoberman

reviews.text: Gravity is less a feature film than cinema as experience: a new frontier in filmmaking that will appeal to studios trying to attract people to movie theaters.
reviews.author: Sonny Bunch

reviews.text: It's the very definition of a thriller, from the mysterious locale to the unpredictably tumultuous events containing no hope of survival.
reviews.author: Jared Mobarak

reviews.text: It is a big, bold picture that refuses to be timid, and it left me trembling. It's not just a film; it's something that happens to you.
reviews.author: Jason Bailey

reviews.text: It is exhilarating film-making, engineered with dizzying invention, and it combines commanding 3D digital effects -- some of the best I've ever seen -- with a surprisingly soulful touch.
reviews.author: Edward Lawrenson

reviews.text: Gravity becomes a character study driven by a riveting central performance and a radical thrill ride delivered with near real-time urgency which thrusts you through its implausibilities.
reviews.author: Russell Baillie

reviews.text: Beautiful and poetic, the image of small humans in fathomless space is also elegiac and eventually frightening.
reviews.author: Kong Rithdee

reviews.text: Gravity dazzles with images that place us at the center of space flight...but keeps yanking us into a contrived fantasy version of space in which, among other things, the world's space stations are all lined up, like a low-orbit trailer park.
reviews.author: Bill Newcott

reviews.text: So it was good, if a bit jarring, to feel myself shrink at the film's beginning, when I found myself floating above the surface of the earth for a little while in absolute silence.
reviews.author: Alissa Wilkinson

reviews.text: The film's impressiveness begins and ends with its sizzle-reel mentality, never amounting to much more than a dazzling technical exercise starring some really famous people.
reviews.author: J. Olson

reviews.text: A work of techno-art, with images of humbling grandeur and scenes almost painful in the depth of horror they evoke.
reviews.author: Rob Gonsalves

reviews.text: The CGI is flawless, and the beautiful shot construction is staggering.
reviews.author: Chris Stuckmann

reviews.text: You don't have to love sci-fi to love Gravity, you just have to love the power of cinema to provide a transcendent experience.
reviews.author: Mark Hughes

reviews.text: One of the greatest man-versus-nature movies in cinematic history.
reviews.author: Richard Knight

reviews.text: $90,000,000, a hundred, whatever they spent: this is a taut thriller built for audiences but also one of the most expensive experimental movies ever made. It's a thrill ride, but a work by a visual artist at the extremes of his acuity.
reviews.author: Ray Pride

reviews.text: An escape from the past that is simultaneously a flight to no future.
reviews.author: Dan Jardine

reviews.text: One of the best science fiction movies in years.
reviews.author: Sherilyn Connelly

reviews.text: This is a story about people floating through space, and Alfonso Cuarón's feature brilliantly contrives to make the viewer feel similarly untethered, to often thrilling effect. This is surely the closest cinema comes to three-dimensional virtual abseiling.
reviews.author: Jonathan Romney

reviews.text: The single most stressful two hours you can have in a movie theatre - in the best possible way.
reviews.author: Rima Sabina Aouf

reviews.text: Surely there are Oscar nominations for all involved, and Gravity is set to be a classic.
reviews.author: Mike Barnard

reviews.text: What could easily have been a dull practice in CGI is crafted by Alfonso Cuaron in to a journey for survival and learning how to cherish life...
reviews.author: Felix Vasquez Jr.

reviews.text: For all the complicated CG wizardry and ostensibly visionary gloss...[Gravity] is aesthetically and structurally regressive.
reviews.author: Jake Cole

reviews.text: We've seen films set in outer space before, but nothing has ever felt this real.
reviews.author: Bryan Bishop

reviews.text: A sleek, smooth, immersive, and rather overwhelming spectacle of economy, efficiency, and all-around proficiency.
reviews.author: Michael Dequina

reviews.text: One of the ten best films of 2013.
reviews.author: Fr. Chris Carpenter

reviews.text: If Cuarón's long-gestating thriller is perhaps not quite the masterpiece we were hoping for, it is still a thrilling and visually striking work.
reviews.author: Martin Roberts

reviews.text: A marvel of performance and effect utilizing the man against his environment/survival motif to justify visual and technical elegance and brilliance.
reviews.author: Jordan Hiller

reviews.text: You want to admire the technical achievement, except it never feels like a technical achievement. It just feels like you're there. And desperately want to leave.
reviews.author: Will Leitch

reviews.text: This masterpiece perfectly blends the elements of a science fiction blockbuster- A-list stars and amazing special effects- with a powerful and subtle story.
reviews.author: John Hanlon

reviews.text: Cuaron's knack for long takes amplifies the terror, where devastation approaches without a sound and that thump you hear could very well be your own pulse.
reviews.author: Radheyan Simonpillai

reviews.text: It's a technical marvel -- appropriately breathtaking in its evocation of space's vastness and the buffeting suffered by the two astronauts in their efforts to anchor themselves to something solid. But Cuaron also knows how suspense works.
reviews.author: Sandra Hall

reviews.text: Gravity is, in the end, a perfect melding of the technological and the emotional.
reviews.author: Sean P. Means

reviews.text: An absolute technical marvel in every way possible -- from cinematography to special effects to sound design to score, all of Gravity's technical parts work together in perfect harmony for maximum effectiveness.
reviews.author: Kate Erbland

reviews.text: Cuarón crucially knows how to deliver spectacle in a way that still counts -- and at a time when practically anything that can be imagined on the page can now be realised on screen, that's no mean feat.
reviews.author: Alistair Harkness

reviews.text: I was on the edge of my seat.
reviews.author: Margaret Pomeranz

reviews.text: Despite these flaws, Gravity is an amazing experience.
reviews.author: David Stratton

reviews.text: Gravity asks that you think about these more lasting effects. And for that, and despite its distractions, its sad mother, its astronauts and ham radio connections, the movie is gorgeous and moving, more about possibility than credibility.
reviews.author: Cynthia Fuchs

reviews.text: A modern science-fiction classic that follows a fractured mother struggling to find herself in the vastness of space.
reviews.author: Wesley Lovell

reviews.text: Bullock's almost balletic performance imbues this vertiginous fantasy with a humanity and grace that beautifully complements director Alfonso Cuarón's breathtaking vision.
reviews.author: Damon Wise

reviews.text: With Hollywood recycling and "rebooting" the same stories and sights more than ever, Gravity stands out as a spectacle not to be missed.
reviews.author: Bill Clark

reviews.text: That is probably one of the best acted, most visually stunning adventure films ever.
reviews.author: Widgett Walls

reviews.text: Can one smell bull**** in space?
reviews.author: Thelma Adams

reviews.text: Gravity resembles a cutting-edge video game more than it does a wholeheartedly immersive cinematic experience...
reviews.author: David Nusair

reviews.text: Created through a painstaking combination of physical and digital performance that disintegrates the divide between live action and animation, Gravity boasts a level of sheer visual invention that would have left Stanley Kubrick's head spinning.
reviews.author: Mark Kermode

reviews.text: Jaw-dropping wonder, dizzying vertigo, heart-stopping tension, spine-tingling shocks and visceral fear: Gravity stimulates them all... Bullock's vital signs [are] being monitored; that probably wouldn't be a bad idea for the viewer, too.
reviews.author: Jason Best

reviews.text: The environment is entirely alien, the technology necessary to live in it has gone far beyond our ken, and humans float around haplessly waiting for the next systemic breakdown... It's hard not to identify with that set of circumstances.
reviews.author: Eileen Jones

reviews.text: A nail-biting journey that's as nerve-wracking as it is technically impressive.
reviews.author: Graham Young

reviews.text: The plot is one-track, the cast minimal and the pace leisurely. But it's a real pleasure to experience space in a movie without an alien in sight.
reviews.author: David Edwards

reviews.text: One can easily imagine Robert Louis Stevenson or H Rider Haggard getting a kick out of Gravity.
reviews.author: Donald Clarke

reviews.text: More like a 91-minute thrill-ride than an astronaut adventure movie, this tour de force throws us out into space without a safety line then thrills us with a series of near misses that take our breath away.
reviews.author: Rich Cline

reviews.text: Stunningly accomplished space survival adventure: heartstopping and heartbreaking; the best film of 2013 so far. Just don't call it science fiction.
reviews.author: MaryAnn Johanson

reviews.text: In space no one can hear you scream. No one can hear your jaw drop either.
reviews.author: Henry Fitzherbert

reviews.text: It's a bumpy trip, with two voyagers carrying, some will argue, excess charisma baggage. But it's a trip no space spectacle fan should miss.
reviews.author: Nigel Andrews

reviews.text: Gripping and utterly immersive space thriller with awe-inspiring visuals, state-of-the-art special effects, unmissable 3D work and a terrific central performance from Sandra Bullock.
reviews.author: Matthew Turner

reviews.text: The film looks and feels so real you have to remind yourself virtually everything on screen doesn't actually exist.
reviews.author: Rob Daniel

reviews.text: Everyone in for a unique cinematic ride against the backdrop of the abyss of outer space will have a fantastic time.
reviews.author: Pamela Jahn

reviews.text: Director and co-writer Cuarón brilliantly manages to create both awe at his glorious space vistas, and knuckle-gobbling tension at what's happening in the foreground.
reviews.author: Peter Bradshaw

reviews.text: Finally the 3D film to knock your socks off. Mexican director Alfonso Cuarón's Gravity is a spectacular watch, which leaves you with a jaw dropping, head spinning, truly immersive space experience.
reviews.author: Brian Henry Martin

reviews.text: The film of the year.
reviews.author: Ian Nathan

reviews.text: a masterpiece of both action and psychology
reviews.author: Andrea Chase

reviews.text: Like the title suggests, this is an astronaut adventure whose pull is hard to resist. By the time 90 stomach-shrinking minutes have elapsed, you'll feel like you've been bumped around the heavens.
reviews.author: James Mottram

reviews.text: I would hate to make Gravity sound like nothing more than a technical achievement. The film does have a theme, and uses the marvels of its imagery to drive that meaning home.
reviews.author: Stuart Klawans

reviews.text: Keeps the tension at white-knuckle levels, evoking the paradoxically claustrophobic emptiness of space as the astronaut faces dangers intimate (asphyxiation) and existential (the void).
reviews.author: John Beifuss

reviews.text: Revolutionary in style and scope and one of the most audience-immersive films ever made.
reviews.author: Bruce Bennett

reviews.text: "Gravity" is a visual marvel, yet it's more than eye candy.
reviews.author: Greg Maki

reviews.text: A spectacular film that, for once, lives up to the hype
reviews.author: Victoria Luxford

reviews.text: The special effects are awesome while the storyline is just okay
reviews.author: Jackie K. Cooper

reviews.text: The stunning vista of the Earth spinning below, the scale of the emptiness, the distances, the astronauts and wreckage tumbling through the void...This is what 3D was made for.
reviews.author: Tim Martain

reviews.text: Less admirable than 2001, but more exciting
reviews.author: Marty Mapes

reviews.text: Makes you feel as if you're floating through space
reviews.author: Robert Denerstein

reviews.text: Breathlessly paced with a procession of nerve-racking cliffhanger moment, Gravity is not just one of the best films about humans in space, it's one of the most tense tales about the power of the survival instinct.
reviews.author: Jim Schembri

reviews.text: As a technical achievement, it's unparalleled...and its depiction of courage leaves a lasting impression. The little triumphs are always tempered by huge moments of melancholy and doubt, because there's always more harrowing danger just around the corner.
reviews.author: Eric Melin

reviews.text: Once the hype and hysteria descend from orbit, it'll be nice to have Gravity simply be what it is - an exciting, accomplished and flawed film from a director willing to take risks in the name of discovery.
reviews.author: James Rocchi

reviews.text: Much less than meets the eye. A victim once again of the professional critic's blurb machinery.
reviews.author: Louis Proyect

reviews.text: While the movie is very heavy on special effects and dazzling visuals, the part of it that impressed me most was the very personal emotional journey of Stone (Bullock).
reviews.author: Robert Roten

reviews.text: Um filme que respeita a Ciência mesmo colocando-a totalmente a serviço do Drama, revelando-se, no processo, como um dos melhores trabalhos de 2013.
reviews.author: Pablo Villaça

reviews.text: Isn't just a great movie, it's a great experience that frequently astonishes, captivates and embraces the challenge of raising the bar on what we should expect from modern day films.
reviews.author: Jeffrey Lyles

reviews.text: Blessed be the innovators but those interested in timelessness need to hire some writers and restore the basics to their rightful place in the cinematic firmament.
reviews.author: Ed Whitfield

reviews.text: In terms of old-fashioned, cliffhanger thrills, Gravity leads the pack this year. It plays like an extended version of the 'Open the pod-bay doors, HAL' sequence in Kubrick's '2001.'
reviews.author: Glenn Lovell

reviews.text: Totally glad I made the decision not to become an astronaut.
reviews.author: Bob Grimm

reviews.text: The most exciting science-fiction space adventure ever made.
reviews.author: Kelly Vance

reviews.text: Gravity is what cinema at its best should be - an experience that makes you grip the armrests tightly and slide to the edge of your seat as you become completely consumed by the story on the screen.
reviews.author: Beth Accomando

reviews.text: "Gravity", a beautiful dance in space that is the closest replica anyone could ever ask for. Easily my favorite film of 2013.
reviews.author: Jolene Mendez

reviews.text: Alfonso Cuarón's film comes with a powerful force of its own - one which drags you towards the edge of your seat, forces your nails down into the cinema arm rests and sucks the breath out of you.
reviews.author: Amber Wilkinson

reviews.text: By all means, see it. But if it actually does change your idea of cinema, you might want to see more movies.
reviews.author: Ken Hanke

reviews.text: Once the lights fade and darkness envelops the theatre you're part of Stone's journey through the infinite.
reviews.author: Simon Reynolds

reviews.text: nothing if not a technical tour de force, possibly one of the greatest examples in recent years of how far cinematic technology can take us into experiences-both visceral and emotional-that most of us are unlikely to ever encounter
reviews.author: James Kendrick

reviews.text: Hugely moving and even, at times, terrifying, this is, without a doubt, the best mainstream American pic of the year thus far - gasp!
reviews.author: David 'Mad Dog' Bradley

reviews.text: Short But Engaging
reviews.author: Diana Saenger

reviews.text: An eye-popping, digital/live-action marvel with new levels of sophistication in its groundbreaking special effects that leaves most other films looking like they're lagging light years behind.
reviews.author: Neil Pond

reviews.text: A minimalist masterpiece that more than merits the response it's gotten from the public and critics alike. How fitting, given its subject, that the acclaim has been universal.
reviews.author: Rick Kisonak

reviews.text: A triumph of nuance that imagines something from a source of simplicity and then wraps it in a cloak of wonderment, despair, alarm and sometimes outright horror.
reviews.author: David Keyes

reviews.text: The cliché 'edge of your seat' seems too mild for this exciting outer space thriller that combines technical magic with strong emotional pull.
reviews.author: Betty Jo Tucker

reviews.text: So many effects-heavy films promise to show you something you've never seen before. Gravity delivers.
reviews.author: Ethan Alter

reviews.text: Alfonso Cuarón makes it look effortless in Gravity, sculpting exemplary sound design, breathtaking images and 3D technology into a film that plunges the viewer straight to the heart of a sweat-inducing, pulse-racing nightmare scenario.
reviews.author: Allan Hunter

reviews.text: A breathtakingly tense sci-fi thriller, a dazzling special-effects showcase that uses state-of-the-art technology to put us right in the spacesuits.
reviews.author: Eric D. Snider

reviews.text: Alfonso Cuarón is among the world's finest, most versatile filmmakers, and someone who hasn't yet directed a dud. Gravity is quite OK too, but in the second tier of his work.
reviews.author: Gerald Peary

reviews.text: A rendering of space in all its magisterial and exotic grandeur -- not only from what we've seen in footage and stills, but in the context of human presence, devastation, utter loneliness and salvation.
reviews.author: Jules Brenner

reviews.text: Buckle up for a relentlessly-riveting, roller coaster ride through a deceptively-close outer space you can virtually reach out and touch!
reviews.author: Kam Williams

reviews.text: If I found a lamp, and a genie came out and granted me three wishes, I'd use one to raise Kubrick so I could take him to Gravity ... No element is out of place, no intention unrealized ... unity of time, place and character ... a work of the highest art.
reviews.author: CJ Johnson

reviews.text: ... the most spectacular and most accurate portrayal of how and why things work and fail in space... on IMAX and in 3D is finally and absolutely worth the price of admission.
reviews.author: Kevin A. Ranson

reviews.text: Perhaps the most remarkable thing is how the film makes the infinite vastness of outer space feel so intimate.
reviews.author: Todd Jorgenson

reviews.text: visually beautiful and the science for the most part seems on the money right down to how the spacesuits move in a weightless environment.
reviews.author: Mark R. Leeper

reviews.text: An elegant space film, with some of the best photography ever.
reviews.author: Dennis Schwartz

reviews.text: An instant classic.
reviews.author: Scott Nash

reviews.text: To be frank, it's not Cuarón's best picture, not with Y Tu Mamá También and Children of Men on his resume. Yet what it lacks in sociopolitical heft and laser-point characterizations it makes up for in sheer visual spectacle.
reviews.author: Matt Brunson

reviews.text: Believe the hype: Gravity is as jaw-droppingly spectacular as you've heard - magnificent from a technical perspective but also a marvel of controlled acting and precise tone.
reviews.author: Christy Lemire

reviews.text: The closet I've ever been to being in space. There are times when you want to ask Sandra and George to move over because they and the so-so story are blocking the view.
reviews.author: Gary Wolcott

reviews.text: A magnificent thriller, and one of the most dumbfoundingly impressive technological feats in the 20 years since Jurassic Park put the world on notice about CGI.
reviews.author: Tim Brayton

reviews.text: [VIDEO ESSAY] "Gravity" leaves the viewer with indelible memories that traverse between fantasy and nightmare flashbacks like an energizing pattern between positive and negative polarities.
reviews.author: Cole Smithey

reviews.text: Bullock and Clooney are good at playing themselves, but it felt like they "phoned" it in making the film feel shallow. Some nice visuals, but nothing that we haven't seen in far better Space films.
reviews.author: Michelle Alexandria

reviews.text: Cuaron and his team have crafted a masterpiece that is so much more than it seems. All the pieces come together to form one of the most unforgettable movie-going experiences of recent memory.
reviews.author: Jeff Beck

reviews.text: ...a super-expensive thriller, at heart like many others, that I enjoyed reasonably well.
reviews.author: Luke Y. Thompson

reviews.text: Gravity has such a big screen scope, 3D clarity and gripping story that it'd be a crime to simply wait for Blu-ray to watch it.
reviews.author: Kevin Carr

reviews.text: Cuaron thrusts us into the heavens for an adventure so lifelike you can almost reach out and touch the stars. And who wouldn't want to reach out and touch George Clooney and Sandra Bullock?
reviews.author: Al Alexander

reviews.text: [The] director's last effort was another great science-fiction movie, "Children of Men," which was borne of ideas. This one celebrates sensation. And it deserves to be one.
reviews.author: Jeffrey M. Anderson

reviews.text: A milestone in cinema. Ask me in twenty-five years about the most magical moviegoing excursions I've had, and I'm pretty sure I'll cite the day I saw Gravity as one of them.
reviews.author: Mike McGranaghan

reviews.text: "Gravity" is a knock out, but without Bullock's movie-star charisma and everywoman relatability, the film wouldn't work nearly as well as it does.
reviews.author: Leonard Maltin

reviews.text: An intense visual wonder from Alfonso Cuaron with no extraneous BS. See it in 3-D if you can.
reviews.author: Clint O'Connor

reviews.text: Given what Cuarón has done here for the film medium, Gravity is nothing less than a 5-star 2001 Space Odyssey for a whole new generation of movie lovers. Take the ride.
reviews.author: Kofi Outlaw

reviews.text: Unfolding as a series of terrifying object lessons in Newtonian physics, the movie lends new meaning to the phrase "spatial geometry."
reviews.author: Christopher Orr

reviews.text: Let's just say seeing the film is the next best thing to the horror and beauty of being lost in space.
reviews.author: Matt Kelemen

reviews.text: Intense, astonishing sci-fi thriller has real soul.
reviews.author: S. Jhoanna Robledo

reviews.text: Gravity is 90 relentlessly frightening, unexpectedly moving minutes. It'll leave you shaking.
reviews.author: Dave White

reviews.text: Not since Stanley Kubrick's 1968 masterpiece 2001: A Space Odyssey has a mainstream film featured space exploration in such an evocative, heady, and realistic manner.
reviews.author: Kirk Baird

reviews.text: Gravity doesn't travel any new ground with the space story. It just takes what has become standard and powers it into the cinema stratosphere with visuals that can't be fully appreciated in a single viewing and a story that is full of emotional fireworks.
reviews.author: Rick Bentley

reviews.text: Cuaron's real victory in the film and his use of 3D is the way he lets it acquire an important role in the storytelling, because it allows the viewer to really get a sense of the unfathomable emptiness and isolation just above the clouds.
reviews.author: Katherine Monk

reviews.text: Gravity is not a film of ideas, like Kubrick's techno-mystical 2001, but it's an overwhelming physical experience -- a challenge to the senses that engages every kind of dread.
reviews.author: David Denby

reviews.text: Nerve-racking, sentimental and thrilling, Gravity honors terra firma even as it reaches for the stars with Sandra Bullock and George Clooney.
reviews.author: Lisa Kennedy

reviews.text: Cuarón and his cinematographer, Emmanuel Lubezki, keep the audience in weightless suspension right along with the astronauts. For most of us, Gravity is the closest we will ever get to the real deal.
reviews.author: Peter Rainer

reviews.text: Here is a movie that is everything a movie should be: relentlessly suspenseful and packed with cutting-edge effects while it's simultaneously filled with emotional gravity.
reviews.author: Robert Levin

reviews.text: An immersive masterwork -- a game-changer, both for the sci-fi genre and Hollywood filmmaking as a whole.
reviews.author: Brent Simon

reviews.text: The filmmakers put you out there with Ryan for 90 sweaty-palmed minutes.
reviews.author: Robin Clifford

reviews.text: ... a Worst-Space Scenario, in which everything that can go wrong does. It's basically 'Sandra Bullock and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Space Walk.'
reviews.author: Jeffrey Overstreet

reviews.text: Despite my few misgivings, I must admit that "Gravity" is an amazing experience.
reviews.author: Jeanne Kaplan

reviews.text: "Gravity" is an instant contender for Best Picture at the 2014 Academy Awards. And the buzz around Bullock as a possible Best Actress nominee is legitimate and well-founded.
reviews.author: David Kaplan

reviews.text: ... with mind-boggling special effects, wonderful 3-D, and award-quality acting by Bullock, this is a movie not to be missed!
reviews.author: Tony Medley

reviews.text: A gonzo, gorgeous, brilliantly executed nightmare of a film.
reviews.author: Brian Juergens

reviews.text: It's a movie that's not afraid to go deep or stare blankly at you to see if it can get you to blink first.
reviews.author: Phil Villarreal

reviews.text: This matter-of-fact thriller disdains sensationalism. Yet, the situations have you holding your breath as each new challenge or obstacle impedes the astronauts as they use their knowledge to find ways to stay alive.
reviews.author: Bob Bloom

reviews.text: Combines a breathtaking use of 3D photography, terrifying action sequences and an emotionally gripping performance by Sandra Bullock to create a brilliant movie.
reviews.author: Lori Hoffman

reviews.text: Cuaron is as eager to invoke primal, instinctual fear as he is to indulge lyrical, philosophical reflection.
reviews.author: John Serba

reviews.text: This is a movie for movie theaters. This is a film that cannot be appreciated to its full extent off of the big screen. Gravity is why movie theaters exist.
reviews.author: Matthew Razak

reviews.text: What immediately strikes you about 'Gravity' is how real everything looks. It's easy to think you're watching an IMAX documentary instead of Bullock and Clooney playing pretend.
reviews.author: Mathew DeKinder

reviews.text: An incredible, flawless, irresistible, white-knuckle, pound-your-head-against-the-wall-like-a-gorilla-smashing-coconuts exercise in technique.
reviews.author: Rob Vaux

reviews.text: As an experience of pure cinema, an appreciation of its ability to show terrible and wonderful things, I can't think of its equal in 2013.
reviews.author: Rob Thomas

reviews.text: As of right now, there's just nothing else like it. And that is a rare treat at the movies.
reviews.author: Justin Craig

reviews.text: Cuarón is so successful at immersing viewers in the astronauts' environment that Gravity is only marginally hampered by its flaws.
reviews.author: Jason Anderson

reviews.text: A dazzling breakthrough for a director more gifted than even his many admirers may have suspected.
reviews.author: Kurt Loder

reviews.text: Visually amazing, wonderfully suspenseful, and rooted in a place of humanity. A stellar popcorn movie.
reviews.author: Scott Weinberg

reviews.text: Gravity, a weightless ballet and a cold-sweat nightmare, intimates mystery and profundity, with that mixture of beauty and terror that the Romantics called the sublime.
reviews.author: Liam Lacey

reviews.text: Doctoral theses will be penned on the breath-catchingly realistic, gorgeously choreographed, entirely mesmerizing opening ...
reviews.author: Bob Mondello

reviews.text: At a scant 90 minutes, director Alfonso Cuarón's dramatic mystery/science-fiction/thriller will absolutely enthrall most viewers. I was riveted.
reviews.author: Jonathan W. Hickman

reviews.text: The most surprising and impressive thing about "Gravity" isn't its scale, its suspense, or its sense of wonder; it's that, in its heart, it is not primarily a film about astronauts, or space, or even a specific catastrophe.
reviews.author: Matt Zoller Seitz

reviews.text: I like the movie's hopefulness, so against the grain of the end-of-everything scowling that we find in every other movie and TV show these days.
reviews.author: Gary Thompson

reviews.text: In the end "Gravity" has only the most basic things to say, but it says them so well and presents them so marvelously that it's a cinematic wonder.
reviews.author: Tom Long

reviews.text: "Gravity" is one of the once-to-a-generation films that transform our sense of the immensity of space and the potential of film.
reviews.author: Nell Minow

reviews.text: Alfonso Cuarón and his son, Jonás, have penned a fantastic yet credible story of courage, friendship, and survival. Even the title, 'Gravity,' is appropriate in its dual simplicity. (This) is a perfect movie. Seeing it in IMAX-3D is perfection plus.
reviews.author: Steve Crum

reviews.text: A gorgeous 90 minute long panic attack that caresses the soul while it obliterates the senses
reviews.author: Cameron Williams

reviews.text: Gravity is the game-changing film of our generation. Cuaron has created a technical and emotional masterpiece that elevates the art form! See the film in IMAX 3D!
reviews.author: Kevin McCarthy

reviews.text: Moves us closer to an art-house/blockbuster hybrid paradigm that could be Hollywood's salvation...a survivalist adventure that captures the primal terror of present death while exploring the will or won't to live.
reviews.author: Peter Canavese

reviews.text: Gravity is a once in a generation film event.
reviews.author: Stephen Lambrechts

reviews.text: Get ready for a mind blowing, stomach churning, popcorn dropping space adventure that might be the most exciting movie you see all year.
reviews.author: Willie Waffle

reviews.text: Cuaron has made a cinematic landmark that features mindblowing effects, relatable characters, and a career best performance from Sandra Bullock. GRAVITY is easily the best film of the year so far
reviews.author: Austin Kennedy

reviews.text: Cuaron has broken extraordinary ground here, creating a film-going immersion in outer space that, at least for those of us who've gotten no closer than an airplane allows, feels unfailingly right.
reviews.author: Greg Evans

reviews.text: Gravity is a celebration of the primal pleasure of movies.
reviews.author: Rene Rodriguez

reviews.text: A viscerally exhilarating 91-minute thrill ride. It won't be remembered for its dialogue or characters, just for its game-changing sound and visual effects. Its style becomes its substance.
reviews.author: Avi Offer

reviews.text: If you can get past the heartstring-tugging, the amped up soundtrack, and George Clooney's relentless Clooneyness, this stunning space saga is the very reason we go to the movies.
reviews.author: Joe Lozito

reviews.text: A true exercise in visual filmmaking and storytelling.
reviews.author: Anders Wright

reviews.text: This is one of the most stunning visual treats of the year and one of the most unforgettable thrill rides in recent memory.
reviews.author: Richard Roeper

reviews.text: Spring for the IMAX 3D if you can, for the most immersive experience and the most realistic approximation of spaceflight this side of the moon.
reviews.author: Chris Knight

reviews.text: Like the movie itself, Bullock is brilliant, taking us inch by inch through Stone's alternating panic, despair, hope and hopelessness in the chaotic struggle to survive.
reviews.author: Jim Lane

reviews.text: The year's great cinematic visual achievement.
reviews.author: Carla Meyer

reviews.text: An unforgettable experience.
reviews.author: Perry Seibert

reviews.text: Prepare to return your jaw to its upright position.
reviews.author: Luke Buckmaster

reviews.text: Gravity is magical, the kind of movie that will inspire a generation of kids to grab cameras and let their imaginations run wild, the proverbial face that launches a thousand ships.
reviews.author: David Medsker

reviews.text: 90 minutes of sheer excitement and terror, a dizzyingly participatory experience.
reviews.author: Devin Faraci

reviews.text: It strives to bring cinema's past, especially the rip-roaring, edge-of-the-seat thrillers Hollywood used to make, into its technological, weightless, oxygen-free future.
reviews.author: Andrew O'Hehir

reviews.text: One of the most exhilarating experiences I've had in the cinema in recent memory.
reviews.author: Steve Newall

reviews.text: One of the most intense theater-going experiences I've had in years. It is more than just a great movie, it's a giant leap forward for the art of cinema.
reviews.author: Kristian Harloff

reviews.text: This enthralling tale of survival in space will open up young audiences' eyes to the excitement of out-of-this-world exploration -- and make older audiences remember the wonder they felt at 2001: A Space Odyssey.
reviews.author: Michael Sragow

reviews.text: As Cuarón spells out in his intro: "Life in space is impossible". So is forming any emotional attachment to Gravity.
reviews.author: Erick Weber

reviews.text: Gravity is the kind of enthralling, all-encompassing, giddy cinematic experience that surfaces once in a blue moon.
reviews.author: Claudia Puig

reviews.text: Shockingly exciting.
reviews.author: Richard von Busack

reviews.text: a cinematic spectacle without equal
reviews.author: Jay Antani

reviews.text: "Gravity" opens with a bravura sequence that is a genuine jaw-dropper. A game-changer. A paradigm of the sheer potency cutting-edge cinema can muster.
reviews.author: Jon Niccum

reviews.text: The movie isn't perfect. But it provides a perfect moviegoing experience, and that's almost as good. The second time I went I watched a lot of the faces in the audience, and they looked just as I imagine mine did the first night I saw it: Whoa.
reviews.author: Wesley Morris

reviews.text: It's a rare combination of jaw-dropping special effects and visual artistry, and it also works as slam-bang entertainment with just two actors and a swift running time of 90 minutes.
reviews.author: Rafer Guzman

reviews.text: An existential action movie that unashamedly embraces the sensation of awe.
reviews.author: Chris Vognar

reviews.text: Words can do little to convey the visual astonishment this space opera creates. It is a film whose impact must be experienced in 3-D on a theatrical screen to be fully understood.
reviews.author: Kenneth Turan

reviews.text: A wildly suspenseful zero-g tale of survival 350 miles beyond the ozone layer, Alfonso Cuarón's space saga is emotionally jolting - and physically jolting, too.
reviews.author: Steven Rea

reviews.text: Yet Gravity also has an emotional and spiritual depth that, like 127 Hours, another film about man versus isolation, transcends what might at first seem a gimmicky plot device.
reviews.author: Cary Darling

reviews.text: That Gravity, in 2013, can make you wonder how it was made with almost every shot, is an incredible achievement. It manages to punch you in the nuts with reality and make you believe in magic all at the same time.
reviews.author: Vincent Mancini

reviews.text: In one form or another, motion pictures have been with us since the middle of the 19th century, but there's never been one like "Gravity."
reviews.author: Joe Morgenstern

reviews.text: "Gravity" must be seen in theaters to be appreciated; the prospect of watching this movie on anything less than a 40-foot screen is tantamount to listening to Beethoven through a tin can and a string.
reviews.author: Ann Hornaday

reviews.text: Even as it looks to the heavens, "Gravity" is bound to earth, where the beauty is in the details.
reviews.author: Joe Williams

reviews.text: Gravity's great gift to the viewer is that it gives outer space back its beauty, terror, and wonder.
reviews.author: Dana Stevens

reviews.text: Kubrick's 2001: A Space Odyssey set the standard for films about space exploration. Until Now. But this one focuses on the human element and boy, are you in for a mind trip with Gravity. The cinematic achievement of the year.
reviews.author: Pete Hammond

reviews.text: Both a claustrophobic suspense thriller and a searing, emotional drama at the same time. And all along, it's absolutely gorgeous.
reviews.author: Stephen Silver

reviews.text: Gravity... may actually be that rarest of beasts: An actual game-changer.
reviews.author: Witney Seibold

reviews.text: A breathtaking film that's visually stunning, emotionally heart-wrenching, and has heart, soul, and even a bit of humor.
reviews.author: Rebecca Murray

reviews.text: Gravity into a thing of transcendent beauty and terror. It's more than a movie. It's some kind of miracle.
reviews.author: Peter Travers

reviews.text: This taut, austere, often wordless film explores the distinction between singularity and loneliness.
reviews.author: Duane Dudek

reviews.text: You can't exactly call Alfonso Cuarón's Gravity the best film of its kind, because it has no kind: It stands alone as an extraordinary balance of 3-D effects, heroes-in-jeopardy storytelling and emotional depth.
reviews.author: Lawrence Toppman

reviews.text: This is a film spectacular enough to demand the full IMAX 3-D treatment.
reviews.author: Marc Savlov

reviews.text: Yes, director Alfonso Cuarón's Gravity is laden with ingenious special effects, but they make for a balletic visual experience that engulfs and transports the audience in a way that very few movies ever have.
reviews.author: Matthew Odam

reviews.text: ...a technical and emotional spectacle, creating a how-did-they-do-that illusion of weightlessness in all its beauty and peril.
reviews.author: Steve Persall

reviews.text: It's an astonishingly controlled piece of filmmaking, particularly given the technological challenges of making it appear the characters are floating in zero gravity.
reviews.author: Chris Hewitt

reviews.text: The visual splendor of "Gravity" is more than a matter of execution; it's also one of imagination.
reviews.author: Mick LaSalle

reviews.text: It's a relief to see an unconventional big-budget studio movie that doesn't hew to the same old pounding action beats, or person-to-person physical violence.
reviews.author: Michael Phillips

reviews.text: Alfonso Cuaron's Gravity is not just out of this world, it is a fresh and exciting new chapter in cinema.
reviews.author: Bruce Kirkland

reviews.text: The film is nothing short of outstanding, particularly if seen on a big IMAX screen in 3D. (Full Content Review for Parents also available)
reviews.author: Jim Judy

reviews.text: Its nimble, acrobatic camera movements are amazing constructions, effortlessly swinging from the vastness of being lost in a black universe to the intimacy of being inside an astronaut's helmet.
reviews.author: Dann Gire

reviews.text: The film uses the cutting edge of technology to take viewers to the far reaches of the human experience, but also to create a sense of empathy.
reviews.author: Keith Phipps

reviews.text: An astonishing technical tour de force and an exciting thrill ride, but as a human drama it barely registers, and it carries none of the metaphysical weight of a film like '2001.'
reviews.author: Frank Swietek

reviews.text: Teeth-clenchingly intense and gloriously immersive. Cuarón demonstrates that cellphone screens and tricked-out home theaters are no match for his big-screen artistry.
reviews.author: Jeff Meyers

reviews.text: It's easy to think, 'Shut up, brain, and just enjoy the view!'
reviews.author: Matt Pais

reviews.text: On the outside Gravity is much like the rest of its ilk - a diagram of the intensity of the human survival instinct; on the inside it is a meditation on the attraction and horror of isolation told with such grace as to take your breath away.
reviews.author: Joshua Starnes

reviews.text: Delivers an exquisite you-are-there head rush, making it one of the most technically sophisticated pictures of the last decade. Gravity is not easily flushed from the system after a viewing.
reviews.author: Brian Orndorf

reviews.text: A technical and storytelling masterpiece buoyed by stunning visuals and functioning both as a ripping, tension-filled yarn and as a profound and life-affirming work of art.
reviews.author: Mike Scott

reviews.text: Not since '2001: A Space Odyssey' has outer space seemed so real.
reviews.author: James Verniere

reviews.text: Not since 2001: A Space Odyssey has a film so vividly and realistically transmitted the feeling of being lost in the cosmos.
reviews.author: Peter Howell

reviews.text: The most important film of 2013 in terms of special effects is also one of its most human, emotional stories. That's the wonder of cinema.
reviews.author: Brian Tallerico

reviews.text: Something almost unheard of these days: a Hollywood spectacle that shows us something new, set in the universe we live in.
reviews.author: Steven D. Greydanus

reviews.text: A soul stirring tale of survival in outer space and an astronaut's spiritual journey.
reviews.author: Frederic and Mary Ann Brussat

reviews.text: ...can't be denied as a landmark visceral experience, even if there are some solid reasons to resist it.
reviews.author: Josh Larsen

reviews.text: That rarest of breeds: the intellectual blockbuster.
reviews.author: Ben Sachs

reviews.text: Gravity, for all its many accomplishments, is at its core a wondrous narrative, beautifully executed with an eye for innovation that matches its emotional and intellectual content.
reviews.author: Jonathan Lack

reviews.text: In a little more than 90 minutes [it] rewrites the rules of cinema as we have known them.
reviews.author: A.O. Scott

reviews.text: If the measure of a film's true greatness is how deeply it immerses you into a world we're unlikely to experience in reality, then Gravity is purely, simply one of the best movies ever made.
reviews.author: Travis Hopson

reviews.text: while the story grabs us at the onset, it's clear homage to "2001's" Starchild in the form of Stone's character coming to grips with the loss of her daughter is so overt, the film's third act loses credibility as it toes its symbolic line.
reviews.author: Laura Clifford

reviews.text: Watch this film on the biggest screen you can find, in 3D IMAX if possible - not to be overwhelmed by its noise and effects, but to join its smart, soulful heroine on her incredible journey and to experience the size of its quietness.
reviews.author: Moira MacDonald

reviews.text: If nothing else, Gravity makes the case for throwing immense resources at true visionaries; the blockbuster craftsman as adventurer, Cuarón expertly blends the epic with the intimate.
reviews.author: A.A. Dowd

reviews.text: The movie impresses us with the vastness and cold emptiness of space as few films have since 2001: A Space Odyssey.
reviews.author: Daniel M. Kimmel

reviews.text: Gravity reminds us how breathtaking cinema can be in its scope and realism.
reviews.author: Julian Roman

reviews.text: Gravity shows how to extract maximum tension from a minimalist story.
reviews.author: Matthew Toomey

reviews.text: For all of its technical prowess, this is a work of pure and unabashedly virtuoso filmmaking from a genuine master of the craft.
reviews.author: Mark Dujsik

reviews.text: As long as Cuarón sticks to the danger and suspense, Gravity is a masterpiece.
reviews.author: Josh Bell

reviews.text: Alarming, intoxicating, eloquent, stomach-tossingly terrifying and emotionally shattering.
reviews.author: Dustin Putman

reviews.text: ...Cuaron takes elements that remove the soul from most films and uses them to his advantage. Gravity opens up the possibilities of cinema. (Video review)
reviews.author: Adam Ross

reviews.text: The movie's an astonishingly detailed, visually painstaking state-of-the-art production that advances what the cinema can show us-even as the human story at its center feels a little thin after a while.
reviews.author: Ty Burr

reviews.text: And it must be said upfront: This experience needs to be taken in on the biggest, IMAX-iest screen possible
reviews.author: Mara Reinstein

reviews.text: If our exploration of space emerged from imagination, science and the spark of inspiration, the extraordinary "Gravity" uses those same tools to craft a movie that might correctly be called a thrill ride with a brain.
reviews.author: Joe Neumaier

reviews.text: Accept Gravity as pure, popcorn-munching show business fun and nothing else, and you won't go away disappointed. Leave logic at the concession stand.
reviews.author: Rex Reed

reviews.text: "Gravity" is an amazing movie for a variety of reasons, not the least of which is how Alfonso Cuaron tells what seems like a familiar type of story in a way we've never seen.
reviews.author: Bill Goodykoontz

reviews.text: Gravity comes loaded with technical wizardry, but Cuaron's visceral, dynamic story-telling is the film's most magical special effect. He makes outer space seem intimate.
reviews.author: Caryn James

reviews.text: Gravity delivers a display of modern technology that leaves the viewer breathless from the experience and marvelling at the craftsmanship behind it.
reviews.author: Thomas Caldwell

reviews.text: Not since Ridley Scott (Alien and Blade Runner) has a filmmaker done more for the Sci-Fi genre. Gravity is undeniable. See it on the biggest screen possible, you will feel the epic profundity of being lost in space.
reviews.author: Blake Howard

reviews.text: Not since Stanley Kubrick's '2001: A Space Odyssey' has there been a sci-fi fantasy as thrilling and intensely gripping as this. Wonderfully innovative, it's an awesome spectacle not to be missed.
reviews.author: Susan Granger

reviews.text: As the credits roll, you may find yourself thinking about real space launches you've watched, or watching man walk on the moon, and remembering that feeling of awe at how man ever developed the technology to explore space in the first place.
reviews.author: Jocelyn Noveck

reviews.text: It has taken until now, with Alfonso Cuarón's "Gravity," for a film to approach the immediacy, beauty, and realism of "2001."
reviews.author: Marc Mohan

reviews.text: The old adage goes, 'They just don't make 'em like they used to.' Alfonso Cuarón's Gravity should inspire a rephrasing: 'They've never made anything like this before.'
reviews.author: Simon Miraudo

reviews.text: Cuarón, a magician who brought personality to the Harry Potter series, is after pure, near-experimental spectacle.
reviews.author: Joshua Rothkopf

reviews.text: Nearly everything about "Gravity" feels right, from its appropriate but compact running time to its satisfying conclusion.
reviews.author: Randy Myers

reviews.text: Alfonso Cuarón's 'Gravity' is a game changer for deep space movies
reviews.author: Kirk Honeycutt

reviews.text: A visually enthralling popcorn movie with two big stars (Sandra Bullock and George Clooney) that will rivet vast crowds for every moment of its 90-minute running time with not a second wasted.
reviews.author: Lou Lumenick

reviews.text: There's not much gravity to the script, but this movie with an ironic title is to be seen more than to be heard.
reviews.author: Harvey S. Karten

reviews.text: Your mileage may vary on the film's more spiritual elements, but Gravity will make you believe in the higher power of movies.
reviews.author: Katey Rich

reviews.text: Alfonso Cuarón and his team have created screen spectacle with a searing human dimension, and bring a true sense of wonder to a groundbreaking movie experience.
reviews.author: Kevin Lally

reviews.text: A harrowing, white-knuckle tale from start to finish...Life or death: How much more of a story do you need?
reviews.author: Marshall Fine

reviews.text: An intimate movie of vast proportions, Gravity is a spell bounding groundbreaker that transforms the movie going experience.
reviews.author: Joanna Langfield

reviews.text: Everything about Gravity appears expertly crafted by Cuaron, and superbly realised by his star.
reviews.author: Pauline Adamek

reviews.text: You may never get to fly off to space, but 'Gravity' is the next best thing.
reviews.author: Perri Nemiroff

reviews.text: Gravity is a crowd-pleasing version of what scientists and mathematicians are said to experience in their rarefied sphere-a wondrous fusion of faith and science.
reviews.author: David Edelstein

reviews.text: Alfonso Cuarón's triumph is an invigoratingly clean, elegant display of action choreography, a La Région Centrale you can still take grandma to see.
reviews.author: Eric Henderson

reviews.text: Together with perfect casting and a superb score, Gravity gets its exclamation mark from the astute use of 3D - adding a layer of thrills at key moments. Hell, they're all key moments
reviews.author: Andrew L. Urban

reviews.text: We are on edge throughout. There is no respite, no relief, no safety net and the fact that almost the entire film takes place in space instills tension and claustrophobia. Tranquility is contrasted by chaos; ethereal beauty by destructive disruption
reviews.author: Louise Keller

reviews.text: A great film, perhaps the best film about space, ever.
reviews.author: Paul Chambers

reviews.text: A thrilling ride, a tremendous accomplishment for one of the most gifted filmmakers working today, and an absolute must-see movie, on the biggest screen possible.
reviews.author: Sean O'Connell

reviews.text: Simply the most spectacular movie you'll see this year.
reviews.author: Edward Douglas

reviews.text: High-class hokum 600,000 feet in orbit
reviews.author: Kent Turner

reviews.text: A hard-science tale that offers a uniquely poetic portrait of hope and survival, "Gravity" is a both a virtuoso technical achievement and a powerfully visceral cinematic experience.
reviews.author: Todd Gilchrist

reviews.text: An exhilarating and borderline profound masterpiece.
reviews.author: William Bibbiani

reviews.text: Think Apollo 13 on steroids, and you get the idea.
reviews.author: Scott A. Mantz

reviews.text: Gravity is unlike anything you've experienced in a movie theater this year
reviews.author: Erik Davis

reviews.text: The worst you can say about this claustrophobic, transporting and unbearably tense movie is that it's so grand it spoils you into expecting even more.
reviews.author: Tim Grierson

reviews.text: Watching Gravity often feels like watching an especially long prep reel for Star Tours, without ever being allowed to board the ride.
reviews.author: Ben Kenigsberg

reviews.text: What's astonishing about the film is its hypnotic seamlessness - the way that the director, Alfonso Cuarón, using special effects (and 3D) with a nearly poetic simplicity and command, places us right up there in space along with the people on screen.
reviews.author: Owen Gleiberman

reviews.text: In short, it's one hell of a ride.
reviews.author: Mike D'Angelo

reviews.text: "Gravity" presents an artificial world that could only have made been today, and provides a fantastic showcase of new possibilities.
reviews.author: Eric Kohn

reviews.text: A visual triumph even if its storytelling is less than sure-footed.
reviews.author: Geoffrey Macnab

reviews.text: Alfonso Cuarón's disaster movie set in space is one of the year's best.
reviews.author: David Jenkins

reviews.text: An awe-inspiring achievement, a towering slice of cinematic splendour that astounds and terrifies in equal measure.
reviews.author: Jordan Farley

reviews.text: This is a movie as much about death as it is about survival.
reviews.author: Zeba Blay

reviews.text: The gut-wrenching, immersive elements are almost above reproach, but ultimately it's all effect and little affect.
reviews.author: Nick McCarthy

reviews.text: Both a technical marvel and a high-tension epic, Gravity is grounded by two perfectly-pitched performances, and launched into the stratosphere by Cuaron's expansive ambition.
reviews.author: Michael Leader

reviews.text: Every once in a while, a film comes along that pushes the form to such an extent that it throws down the gauntlet to other filmmakers, daring them to be as audacious in their craft. This is one of those.
reviews.author: Chris Bumbray

reviews.text: Gravity is the film that cinema was born to make. It echoes the dreams of Meliés writ on a modern giant canvas, yet does so with such impeccable restraint that like the lead characters it will leave you breathless.
reviews.author: Jason Gorber

reviews.text: Gravity is important, relentless and, let's not undersell this, completely entertaining.
reviews.author: Jordan Hoffman

reviews.text: ... with 'Gravity,' [Alfonso Cuaron] seems to have shed the bonds of Earth, and we are fortunate enough to be able to follow him into the unknown.
reviews.author: Drew McWeeny

reviews.text: So it's not a very good movie, but it is a really good spectacle.
reviews.author: Walter Chaw

reviews.text: This isn't just the best-looking film of the year, it's one of the most awe-inspiring achievements in the history of special-effects cinema.
reviews.author: Tom Huddleston

reviews.text: This is truly awesome.
reviews.author: William Goss

reviews.text: 'Gravity' tries so hard to add emotional heft to its simple survival story, but its attempts are labored, unconvincing, and frankly downright dumb. This gorgeous, exciting film didn't need them.
reviews.author: Eugene Novikov

reviews.text: This is seat-chewingly tense, virtuoso cinema that explores and exploits space as never before, with 3-D so convincing the audience lurches and gasps as though on a fairground ride.
reviews.author: Kate Muir

reviews.text: The film's raison d'etre is its considerable technical prowess, enhanced by 3D but in a determinedly ungimmicky way.
reviews.author: Derek Malcolm

reviews.text: I haven't yet fully recovered.
reviews.author: Stephanie Zacharek

reviews.text: For sheer transference of experience upon the audience, I can think of no film quite like it.
reviews.author: Guy Lodge

reviews.text: Gravity is very much an action adventure film, one very occasionally more meditative than most, but it's unashamed in its desire to thrill you.
reviews.author: Oliver Lyttelton

reviews.text: A master class in fluid camerawork, bold, unfussy imagery and special effects that put most recent Hollywood blockbusters to shame.
reviews.author: Jon Frosch

reviews.text: If the film past is dead, Gravity shows us the glory of cinema's future. It thrills on so many levels. And because Cuar‪ón is a movie visionary of the highest order, you truly can't beat the view.
reviews.author: Richard Corliss

reviews.text: With nothingness pressing in on all sides, in a place where the grip of someone else's hand is all that keeps you from the void, life really does seem like a miracle.
reviews.author: Robbie Collin

reviews.text: A brilliantly tense and involving account of two stricken astronauts; a howl in the wilderness that sucks the breath from your lungs.
reviews.author: Xan Brooks

reviews.text: Cuaron's exhilarating and often spectacular 3-D film is a real pleasure, driven by top-notch lead performance from Sandra Bullock and George Clooney as well as some seriously cool special effects.
reviews.author: Mark Adams

reviews.text: At once the most realistic and beautifully choreographed film ever set in space, Gravity is a thrillingly realized survival story spiked with interludes of breath-catching tension and startling surprise.
reviews.author: Todd McCarthy

reviews.text: [A] white-knuckle space odyssey, a work of great narrative simplicity and visual complexity ...
reviews.author: Justin Chang

reviews.text: This is a thrilling and moving rollercoaster of a movie that will appeal to space geeks and romantics alike.
reviews.author: Jon Lyus

synopsis: Dr. Ryan Stone (Sandra Bullock) is a medical engineer on her first shuttle mission. Her commander is veteran astronaut Matt Kowalsky (George Clooney), helming his last flight before retirement. Then, during a routine space walk by the pair, disaster strikes: The shuttle is destroyed, leaving Ryan and Matt stranded in deep space with no link to Earth and no hope of rescue. As fear turns to panic, they realize that the only way home may be to venture further into space.
